t1.description:
OS Process may be spoofed by
          an attacker and this may lead to information disclosure by Generic Data Store. Consider using a standard
          authentication mechanism to identify the destination process.

t2.description:
Generic Data Store may be
          spoofed by an attacker and this may lead to incorrect data delivered to OS Process. Consider using a standard
          authentication mechanism to identify the source data store.
t2.summary: 2. Spoofing of Source Data Store Generic Data Store

t3.description:
Attackers may attempt to
          modify PHI to avoid billing, or to cause misdiagnosis of a patient. Recommend using cryptographic signing to
          protect against modification of PHI.

t4.description:
OS Process claims that it did
          not receive data from a source outside the trust boundary. Consider using logging or auditing to record the
          source, time, and summary of the received data.
t4.summary: 4. Potential Data Repudiation by OS Process

t5.description:
Improper data protection of
          Generic Data Store can allow an attacker to read information not intended for disclosure. Review authorization
          settings.
t5.summary: 5. Weak Access Control for a Resource

t6.description:
OS Process crashes, halts,
          stops or runs slowly; in all cases violating an availability metric.
t6.summary: 6. Potential Process Crash or Stop for OS Process

t7.description:
An external agent interrupts
          data flowing across a trust boundary in either direction.
t7.summary: 7. Data Flow Generic Data Flow Is Potentially Interrupted

t8.description:
An external agent prevents
          access to a data store on the other side of the trust boundary.

t9.description:
Generic Data Store may be
          able to remotely execute code for OS Process.
t9.summary:
9. OS Process May be Subject to Elevation of Privilege Using Remote
        Code Execution

t10.description:
An attacker may pass data
          into OS Process in order to change the flow of program execution within OS Process to the attacker's choosing.
t10.summary: 10. Elevation by Changing the Execution Flow in OS Process

t11.description:
OS Process may be spoofed by
          an attacker and this may lead to unauthorized access to Generic Data Store. Consider using a standard
          authentication mechanism to identify the source process.

t12.description:
Generic Data Store may be
          spoofed by an attacker and this may lead to data being written to the attacker's target instead of Generic
          Data Store. Consider using a standard authentication mechanism to identify the destination data store.
t12.summary: 12. Spoofing of Destination Data Store Generic Data Store

t13.description:
Data flowing across Generic
          Data Flow may be tampered with by an attacker. This may lead to corruption of Generic Data Store. Ensure the
          integrity of the data flow to the data store.
t13.summary: 13. The Generic Data Store Data Store Could Be Corrupted

t14.description:
Generic Data Store claims
          that it did not write data received from an entity on the other side of the trust boundary. Consider using
          logging or auditing to record the source, time, and summary of the received data.
t14.summary:
14. Data Store Denies Generic Data Store Potentially Writing
        Data

t15.description:
Data flowing across Generic
          Data Flow may be sniffed by an attacker. Depending on what type of data an attacker can read, it may be used
          to attack other parts of the system or simply be a disclosure of information leading to compliance violations.
          Consider encrypting the data flow.

t16.description:
Does OS Process or Generic
          Data Store take explicit steps to control resource consumption? Resource consumption attacks can be hard to
          deal with, and there are times that it makes sense to let the OS do the job. Be careful that your resource
          requests don't deadlock, and that they do timeout.
t16.summary:
16. Potential Excessive Resource Consumption for OS Process or
        Generic Data Store

t17.description:
An external agent interrupts
          data flowing across a trust boundary in either direction.
t17.summary: 17. Data Flow Generic Data Flow Is Potentially Interrupted

t18.description:
An external agent prevents
          access to a data store on the other side of the trust boundary.

t19.description:
OS Process may be able to
          impersonate the context of OS Process in order to gain additional privilege.

t20.description:
OS Process may be able to
          impersonate the context of OS Process in order to gain additional privilege.

t21.description:
Generic External Interactor
          may be spoofed by an attacker and this may lead to unauthorized access to OS Process. Consider using a
          standard authentication mechanism to identify the external entity.
t21.summary: 21. Spoofing the Generic External Interactor External Entity

t22.description:
OS Process claims that it did
          not receive data from a source outside the trust boundary. Consider using logging or auditing to record the
          source, time, and summary of the received data.
t22.summary: 22. Potential Data Repudiation by OS Process

t23.description:
OS Process crashes, halts,
          stops or runs slowly; in all cases violating an availability metric.
t23.summary: 23. Potential Process Crash or Stop for OS Process

t24.description:
An external agent interrupts
          data flowing across a trust boundary in either direction.
t24.summary: 24. Data Flow HTTPS Is Potentially Interrupted

t25.description:
OS Process may be able to
          impersonate the context of Generic External Interactor in order to gain additional privilege.

t26.description:
Generic External Interactor
          may be able to remotely execute code for OS Process.
t26.summary:
26. OS Process May be Subject to Elevation of Privilege Using Remote
        Code Execution

t27.description:
An attacker may pass data
          into OS Process in order to change the flow of program execution within OS Process to the attacker's choosing.
t27.summary: 27. Elevation by Changing the Execution Flow in OS Process

t28.description:
Generic External Interactor
          may be spoofed by an attacker and this may lead to data being sent to the attacker's target instead of Generic
          External Interactor. Consider using a standard authentication mechanism to identify the external entity.
t28.summary:
28. Spoofing of the Generic External Interactor External Destination
        Entity

t29.description:
Generic External Interactor
          claims that it did not receive data from a process on the other side of the trust boundary. Consider using
          logging or auditing to record the source, time, and summary of the received data.
t29.summary:
29. External Entity Generic External Interactor Potentially Denies
        Receiving Data

t30.description:
An external agent interrupts
          data flowing across a trust boundary in either direction.
t30.summary: 30. Data Flow HTTPS Is Potentially Interrupted
